titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Always busy, agitating, anxious, and as years advance every time it happens more confusing than the last— As I am this time to travel alone I concluded to take with me but one trunk and an umbrella— Hesitating about the last article, so often needed for shelter from rain or sun; but so liable to be lost, stolen or broken by the way, that about twice out of three times mine is missing at my journey’s end— This days occupation with aid of my wife and nephew was packing up my chest of books and pamphlets and my files of Letters for the last two years to be shipped by the first coaster to Boston, and my strong trunk to be taken with me— Mr Heap called on me this morning, and I returned him his papers, but partly read: He told me he was going by the Cars to-morrow morning, without prospect of any further public employment, and equally unwilling to seek and hopeless to obtain further personal access to President Tyler or Secretary Webster— I received a note from Mr Page the Daguerrotype artist requesting me to call again this day as he was not satisfied with the shades taken on Saturday— I did call accordingly twice, and he took my similitude twice but neither time with much success. At one time he and Mr West took two impressions of me at one sitting, upon two camera obscura’s standing side by side, and shewing the face as by two different angles of refraction. I stop’d at Keyworth’s and took my old silver sleeve buttons relinked after fifteen years of wear— I paid my last visit to Mr Burnell with whom I found as usual his faithful wife and Nurse— They think him convalescent and I hope he is so— While I was there Mr George Brown came in; going to-morrow to Norfolk, Virginia to embark in the Vandalia Sloop of War to be landed at Chagres thence to traverse by land the Isthmus to Panama, and thence to proceed in some vessel of our Pacific Squadron to the seat of his mission to the Hawaÿan Islands. I walked on to the Capitol and there received from Mr Burche, the last sheet of the House journal of the recent Session, and from young Cutts two or three other Documents; but neither the Senate Journal of the last Session; nor the collective house documents of the preceding Session the 2d. of the 27th. Congress were ready for distribution— After dinner Mr Hawley Rector of St. John’s Church called to take leave of me, and enquired if I should incline to rent a pew in the renovated Church having concluded to relinquish that which I now hold. I said I should. Mr Frye came, and gave me a statement of his accounts with me, and Mr Morsell made me an offer of 100 dollars for the lot adjoining the house I sold to him— In both these cases, I procrastinated settlement most neglectfully— Richard D. Cutts and his Sister came and took leave— Up till midnight.

At 6. O’Clock this morning I left the City of Washington in the train of Cars for Baltimore— My nephew Isaac Hull Adams accompanied me to the Railway depot; remaining here to come on with my wife, Mrs John Adams and her daughter Mary Louisa in June. At the Cars I met Mr Heap who came on only as far as Baltimore Captain Williams of the army. Mr Newhall of Lynn, and sundry others who claimed I have no doubt justly, old acquaintance, but whom I do not even now recollect— The morning was clear and fine but cold and there was a white-frost on the ground till we had passed beyond Bladensburg— We reached Baltimore, about a quarter past 8.—and alighting from the Cars, walked immediately to the Steam boat wharf and step’d on board the Steamer Constitution, Captain Chaytor. I think it was over 6. years since I had seen him, and his skin hung about him like an old lady’s loose gown— I asked him if he had been sick—he said no—he was drying up— He had within the last four years, dried off sixty pounds of flesh and I have no doubt he weighs that much less than he did the last time I made a passage in his boat— I scarcely ever saw such a change; and his face looks like a wet cloth ill laid up. In the steamer I saw for a moment the Secretary of the U.S. Senate Asbury Dickens, but he was about to return to Washington; Mr Russell of the interior of the State of New-York; a member of two or three Congresses including the 26th. now returning home from Washington, where he told me he saw yesterday Mr Webster at the Department of State—and he told him he intended to retire from the Department within ten days. Mr Sanderson the first publisher of the biography of the signers of the declaration of Independence; a work of which the first expense was very heavy upon him, and which he was upwards of 5 years in getting through, but of which he afterwards sold the property and the plates, and of which more than twenty Editions have now been published, and the plates have been four times renewed. The last edition is in one octavo volume— Sanderson, said he now kept a public house, in Chesnut Street Philadelphia—the Franklin house, where he would be glad to see me— There was also in the boat Captain Payne of the Navy and his Sister—and a Mr Fessenden, who said he lived at Jamaica Plains, and was now a constituent of mine— We reached French-town at half past 1. then came in the railway cars in 50 minutes to Newcastle, and thence in the Steamer Robert Morris to Philadelphia—at half past 4. I took chamber N. 16. at Jones’s Union Hotel Chesnut Street— In a quarter of an hour more in Mr Richard Rush’s carriage, with his Son Benjamin, I came out to Sydenham, his residence, dined with him and a party of his friends, and agreed at his kind and hospitable invitation to pass the Night here— I retired soon after 11. O’Clock.

After a good night’s rest I rose at five, and having with me this Diary, a steel pen and my small tin-boxed inkstand, wrote the journal of May-day— I then breakfasted with Mr and Mrs. Rush and their two daughters, I suppose about 20 and 18 years old— Their three sons Benjamin, Samuel and Murray were at the dinner last evening, but neither of them at breakfast this morning— Of the company at dinner yesterday were Mr James Smith Wilcocks, Dr Chapman, Mr Petre, the English Consul, Mr White a son of the late Bishop, a Dr Mitchell, a young man named Chew, and one or two others, strangers to me— Mr Wilcocks invited me to dine with him this day; and Mr Rush urged me so cordially to stay and pass the night at his house that I consented,—and accepted Mr Wilcocks’s invitation to dine with him this day. After breakfast, Mr Rush took me in his Carriage and landed me at the door of the Bank of North America in Philadelphia, where I received in Bills of that bank 120 dollars for 4 coupons of 30 dollars each, a half year’s interest on 4. Cincinnati city bonds. Mr Rush then left me, and I went in search of Mr George Rundle Treasurer of the Schuykill permanent Bridge Company. Two or three years since the Legislature of the State nullified the Charter of that company and made the bridge free; a sample of democratic pillage of property just like that of the Legislature of Massachusetts with Charles river Bridge— So Sovereigns, Monarchical or popular always will deal with corporation property— The dividends now made are only the proceeds of sales of the Company’s property— The Legislature gave them the alternative of having another bridge built close at the side of their own, or of surrendering their charter for a compensation of about 75 per cent of the par value of their stock which was at 30 per cent advance in the market, that is they gave them about half the value of their stock, as a consideration for not taking away the whole, by another parallel bridge— After long search I found Mr Rundles house in Locust Street 101. but he was at his office— Another long search for that which I found at last with the help of a young Quaker whom I met in the Street, and after all it was the old Office which I had visited at least ten times.— He paid me three dividends amounting to 96. dollars, by a check on the Philadelphia Bank— Another search for that, which I found with George W. Toland whom I met twice in the street; first with S. D. Ingham, whom I did not recognize; and afterwards withPotts— The President of the Bank J. B. Trion gave me a draft on the Globe Bank at Boston— At 1/2 past 10. Mr Rush came and took me to the house ofRidgway, to attend his funeral; that is to have my name announced as one of the mourners— I then returned to Jones’s Hotel—wrote the Journal of yesterday— Mr Rush called for me again at 1/2 past 4 visited his mother and Sister Mrs. Williams— Took up his two daughters; dined at Mr Wilcocks’s— About 10 in the Evening he took me to the door of Jones’s hotel where I took leave of him and his daughters—

div.dateline: Philadelphia Thursday 4. May 1843. New-York— Steamer Cleopatra.
div.p: There are two lines of daily conveyance— One, departing at 7. in the morning, which after crossing the river to Camden proceeds to Amboy by the Railway to Amboy, and thence in a Steamboat to New-York—arriving there between 2 and 3 O’Clock P.M. The other, crossing the river at 9. and proceeding by the Railway to the Ferry at Powle’s hook, or Jersey city, and arriving at New-York between 3 and 4 P.M— I had determined to take the early line, and for that purpose rose at 5. and wrote till past 6. then breakfasted alone; but being visited while at breakfast by an old ex member of Congress whose name I did not remember was delayed till I had scanty time to reach the wharf— My trunk carried in a hand cart by a man from the hotel but I missed my way, and going first to the chesnut Street and thence to the market street wharf, finally returning to the true walnut street wharf saw the ferry-boat move off from it and lost my passage to Camden— The carrier from Jones’s had just turned round with his cart and was taking my trunk back to the hotel, when by a short race I overtook him, and made him lodge my trunk in the corner room where the ticket office is kept, and it being a public house, engaged a chamber till the next boat should go. had my trunk taken up in the chamber; and there finished writing the journal of yesterday.— I thus avoided the ennui and waste of two lost hours of time and how many such hours I might have saved had I throughout my life resorted to similar expedients— Nine O’Clock came and I had lost no time, and made no arrears of journal— Crossing the river to Camden I met Mr Furness the Unitarian Minister escorting two of his nieces named Osborne, who were returning from a visit of some weeks to him, to their home in Connecticut—he introduced them to me, and recommended them to my attentions.— He left them seated in the Cars, and I took a seat near them. I met too in the boat a man by the name of Bradshaw a native of Massachusetts, who claimed old acquaintance with me, and charged me with having forgotten him, which was true, but which I promised him, should not happen again— In the Cars also there was Mrs. Whitney, wife of one of my neighbours going home from a visit to her daughter— The cars rolled steadyly and smoothly on to the ferry boat at Jersey city, on crossing which to New-York, a young man a brother of the two young Ladies met them and escorted them to the Steamer Cleopatra bound to Norwich, in which I also engagement? was finally to embark— My trunk had been first shipped in the Steamer Rhode Island bound to Stonington, lying on the other side of the wharf I walked round the battery and to the exchange, where I paid a visit to Lewis Tappan, who introduced to me the Revd Mr Raymond returned from the Mendian Mission.

div.dateline: New London. Norwich. Friday 5. May 1843. Boston
div.p: From my visit to Mr Lewis Tappan yesterday afternoon I returned to the Steamer Cleopatra, Captain Dustin at Pier N. 1. adjoining the Battery New-York— At 5. O’Clock precisely she loosened from her moorings at the same time, with the Steamer Rhode-Island from the other side of the Pier, bound to Stonington; whom we soon left astern at least a mile an hour. The two young Ladies nieces of Mr Furness on embarking had retired to the Ladies Cabin, and I saw them no more.— Mrs Whitney had concluded to rest for the Night at New York— I saw her no more; but as fellow passengers I met Mr Thomas W. Williams, a member of the last two Congresses from Connecticut, with his son, a boy about 12 years of age— A Mr Lee of Philadelphia claiming old acquaintance which I remembered not, and a Mr John G. Parker who introduced himself to me, as thankful for very great obligations which I had equally forgotten— He said he was a native of Massachusetts but had resided many years in Canada— That in 1838 he had been arrested on groundless suspicion of being actively concerned in the insurrection against the British Government and sent to England for trial. That a number of Gentlemen here had signed a representation in his favour, to Mr Fox the British Minister at Washington; which he had transmitted to his Government, and in consequence of which he Parker had been discharged— My name he said was signed among others to the representation, and he was happy to have this opportunity to thank me for the favour.— Un bienfait n est jamais perdu— How delightful it is to discover that you have rendered happy grateful hearts, by good offices, not even remembered by yourself— The weather was so fine, and the sea so smooth that the motion of the boat was scarcely perceptib while she was going at least 12 miles an hour. Supper came, which I made to answer for my dinner, and about 8. O’Clock I turned in to my berth N. 69, which the Captain had assigned to me as one of the best in the boat.— After about 5 hours of sound and quiet sleep I awoke soon after one this morning, arose, dressed, washed and was shaved, and went on the deck where I found Mr Williams just ready to land with his son at New London— He took leave of me with a kind invitation, to his house, if I should ever come there again— The sky was cloudless, and the Great and Little Bear, the Scorpion, Balance and Sagittary, the Lyre, Eagle and Dolphin all splendid overhed, but when we landed at Norwich at 1/2 past 2—it was already beclouded. We had barely time to enter the cars and be seated when they started. passed through Worcester just after 6. landed at the depot in Boston a quarter past 8 took a cab and at 1/2 past 8 was greeted by my Son at his house 57 Mount Vernon Street Boston— Wrote to my wife— Called on Mr Leavitt but he was gone to Malden— Evening visit from Mr P. C. Brooks.

I have accepted an invitation from the Massachusetts historical Society, to deliver on the 29th of this month a discourse before them, on the second centennial anniversary of the confederation of the New-England Colonies, and I have come here without and before my family, for the purpose of preparing it— I have paid so little attention to that portion of our history that I scarcely knew the sources at which the principal facts relating to it were to be found—nor have I any clue to the aspect in which it should be viewed for any useful purpose at the present time— Pope makes it a point of self-glorification, that not in fancy’s maze he wander’d long, but stoop’d to truth and moraliz’d his song— I believe that moral principle should be the alpha and omega, of all human composition—poetry or prose scientific or literary written or spoken—and emphatically of every discourse An Epic Poem, a Drama, Pastoral, Georgic or Fable, Ode, Sonnet or epigram should alike spring from one vital seminal principle of morals and so should every History Dissertation, Treatise, Discourse or epistle— Pen should never be put to paper, but for the discharge of some duty to God or man— How then shall I best discharge the duty which I have undertaken of discoursing to my co-associates of the historical Society, and to my fellow Citizens on the New-England Confederation of 1643? What was that confederation—its uses, its origin, its history, its termination—its influence upon the colonies, between whom it was formed; upon their relations with the Indians, with the other English Colonies, with England the mother Country, with the neighbouring Colonies of other Countries; and with the rest of mankind?—and from the result of all these enquiries what sound and useful moral principle can be deduced for the entertainment and instruction of a listening auditory, and of readers here after.— I called at the chambers of the Historical Society. The outer door was locked, with a notice that the Librarian might be found at N 15. Warren street— It was the residence of Mr Joseph B. Felt, whom I found at home where I also saw his wife. He accompanied me to the chambers of the historical Society, and found for me Mather’s Magnalia; the 2d. Volume of Hazard’s collection of State Papers, and three folio volumes of manuscripts which he supposed might assist me in my enquiries. He lent me the keys of the chambers, and promised to call and see me there on Monday. I paid a visit to Mrs Abbott Lawrence: her husband was not at home— I dined with Charles at Mr Peter C. Brooks’s. Walk after dinner. Met Degrand— Evening at home with Charles.

Dr Frothingham preached this morning, from 1. Corinthians 1.18—The whole verse reads “For the preaching of the cross is to them that perish foolishness: but unto us which are saved, it is the power of God”— But the text was only “The preaching of the cross, is the power of God,” and the sermon was a most ingenious and deeply pathetic declamation upon the power of the cross, as a symbol of the sufferings of Christ, and of the doctrines of Christianity— The use of this symbol, has been of the sharpest points of controvery between the Roman Catholic and Protestant Churches.— It has been heretofore a source of much internal dissension in the episcopal church of England, and is even now revived with ominous agitation both in England and here— It extends even beyond the bounds of the episcopal church, and I was somewhat surprised at the vivacity and zeal with which Dr Frothingham seems to have entered into it— Certain it is that the writings of St. Paul, from which the Dr cited several most impressive passages, countenance a reverence for the cross, which endangers the indulgence of idolatry, as all substitution of attachment to the symbol for the love of the object represented, is prone to do— Of these trappings of Roman Catholic worship the Church of England has discarded many and retained more than enough— She has retained the sign of the cross only in the administration of the rite of baptism, where it is made by the finger of the priest over the forehead of the infant, leaving no trace of it behind— But there is at this very moment a bitter struggle in the episcopal church of England to return to the emblematic worship of popery— There was a passage at the close of the Doctor’s discourse, which alluded without censure to the Roman Catholic worship of the virgin mother of Christ, which belongs to the same School of the adoration of the cross— After the morning service, Dr Frothingham administered the communion with admirable and affecting solemnity— I came home through a shower of heavy thunder and sharp Lightening with a mere sprinkling of rain— After dinner Dr Frothinghams text was from the words “whose seed was in itself” from Genesis 1.11. The discourse as usual; ingenious, fanciful, and copious of analogies with a touch of gentle interrogation, as to the value or efficiency of religious missions to distant foreign lands— After church I had a visit from Mr Abbott Lawrence, who invited me to dine with him on Tuesday. Miss Harriet Welsh took tea here— And with Charles and his wife I spent the Evening at Mr P. C. Brooks’s.

On awaking this morning I found my sore throat, hoarseness and catarrh returned upon me in all its severity, and in sitting down to write my hand shaking so that it was with extreme difficulty that I could hold my pen; yet my only labour under the sun is writing, as I have little time to spare in preparation for the 29th. I devoted all the early morning to Hazard’s collection of the records of the United Colonies of New-England— They extend from the 19th. of May 1643 to the 24th of March 1678—35 years—including the Colonies of Massachusetts, Plymouth, Connecticut and New-Haven. Rhode Island applied for admission to the confederacy but was refused. During its continuance New-Haven was merged into the Colony of Connecticut; after which the Confederate Colonies were but 3.— From the beginning there were only two Commissioners for each Colony; at first annually chosen, for yearly meetings; but of later time meeting only once in three years— The records occupy three fourths of a large quarto volume; but as I have to consult many other sources of information, I skimmed over the whole surface of this compilation, and could of course pry deep into nothing— Yet the morning was gone, and I had yesterday’s journal yet to write; which I nevertheless did accomplish— I then sallied forth and at N. 220. Washington Street found my old shaver of last fall, by the name of Cadmus, after passing through whose hands, I went to the Emancipator Office, and had a long conversation with Mr Leavitt— He is to embark next Tuesday in the Steamer for Liverpool, to attend as a delegate from the American, Anti-Slavery Society the second triennial meeting of the World’s convention, for the promotion of the abolition of Slavery and the Slave trade throughout the Earth— I urged him very earnestly to observe with unremitting care the movements of the British Government with regard to Mexico and Texas— I told him I distrusted them altogether— I believed their real policy far from desiring to favour the abolition of Slavery either in our Southern States, or in Texas. I suspect on the contrary, that for a suitable equivalent they will readily acquiesce both in the annexation of Texas to this Union, and to the perpetuation of Slavery here to weaken and to rule us.— Mr P. C. Brooks and his Son, dined with us at my Sons house, and I began at a perfect hazard to write my discourse.

The Catarhh has become feverish, and cruelly torturing— I was twice up in the Night before the time for rising came; and this whole day I have been upon the rack— I find it difficult to sustain my Spirits and have concluded to go out to Quincy next Monday— As my first and most indispensable object is to be prepared for the discourse of the 29th. I find it necessary to begin the day with writing upon it— I wrote accordingly and wasted the morning until Noontide without coming to any point upon which I can dilate, to fill up the time necessary for the delivery The confederacy of the New-England Colonies was a system of concert between the several jurisdictions, for the common defence against the French colonial establishments at the North—the Dutch at the South but especially, and above all against the Indians— Shortly before noon, I went locked myself up in the chambers of the historical Society, and searched for notices of Indian wars and the New England confederacy— I soon found abundance of materials for enquiry, and spent nearly three hours in search, rather for the sources of information than in the examination of what I found— I had no time for that— It was some time before I detected the history of the War with Philip—Sachem of Mount Hope— It forms the 7th. book of Mather’s Magnalia— This work deserves great consideration as a sample of the literary, political, moral and religious condition of the New-England colonies at that time— It is a collection of biographical anecdotes; a nauseous panegyric upon all the principal founders civil and ecclesiastical of the New England colonial settlements. With a history of Harvard College, and a narrative of Indian wars, down to the close of the 17th century— The Style is pedantic; motley coloured with perpetual allusions to the bible, and to the Hebrew, Greek, Latin and English Poets— Among the rest, I was surprised to meet a quotation from the Paradise Lost— I found also numerous articles relating to the Pequot, Mohegan, and Narragansett tribes of Indians—upon all which my discourse should have been preceded by a regular and systematic six months course of reading, for which I have less than three weeks— After 2 I came home and went and dined with Mr Abbott Lawrence. Besides his family, there were his Sister Mrs Green, Miss Leslie the painter’s Sister, and Mr Thacher of Bangor— I came home immediately after dinner, and found Mr Kinnicutt and Mr John T. Bigelow with my Son. Mr Felt came in afterwards, and I agreed to go with him at 11. to-morrow morning to the State-house.

A much disturbed night succeeded by an uncomfortable and unprofitable day— After a visit to Mr Cadmus the barber, I called at Mr James H. Foster’s and saw Mrs Foster and her three daughters Elizabeth, Louisa and Mary— Mr Foster was not at home, and Louisa C. Smith was gone to Medford.— Mr Felt had agreed to meet me at 11. O’Clock this morning at the Secretary’s Office in the State house— But I had misunderstood him that he would call at my Son’s house for me, and would go with me.— After waiting for him till near noon I went to the State house to the room which he formerly occupied, when employed in collecting in volumes, and indexing the records of the general Courts, and the archives of the State. But this office has been suppressed since the first of March.— He was not there and I came home. He was at the same time in the Secretary’s Office where I neglected to call and enquire for him— He was informed that I had been to the other office after him and he then came to Charles’s and accompanied me to the Secretary’s Office— I examined the volume of Records containing the proceedings of the Commissioners of the United Colonies of New-England— Mr Felt made two extracts for me; but I found little, other than what is printed in Hazard’s collections, and the manuscript writing of that age is so difficult for me to read that I shall obtain little or no assistance from these original records— One of the extracts is a vote of the general Court of 8. Septr. 1642. appointing a numerous Committee of Magistrates and deputies, to treat with any Commissioners from Plymouth, Connecticut or New-Haven [“]about the Union and concerning avoiding any danger of the Indians—and to have power to do herein what they shall find needful for common safety and peace, so as they enter not into an offensive War without order of this Court.”— So that the primary object of the Union was the common defence against the Indians— I was able to write only a few lines of my address this day; and at one O’Clock with my Son and his wife with their son John we took up Mr P. C. Brooks at his Office, and went out and dined with Mr Gorham Brooks and his wife at Medford— This day was pleasant, but with an easterly wind, and its cold bath temperature, peculiar to this region at this Season of the year— After dinner we walked round Mr P. C. Brooks’s garden, just beginning to give signs of vegetable life— The desolation of winter still heavy upon it— About Sunset we returned to the City and received notes of invitation from Mrs. Abbott Lawrence, for this Evening— We had engagements already at M Samuel D. Parker’s my Son’s next door neighbour; but I was so unwell that an excuse was sent into Mr Parker’s, and I wait for to morrow to apologize to Mrs Lawrence.

We had received cards of invitation to dine this day with Mr Francis C. Gray; but on Tuesday evening a second note came announcing that by the death of a near relative, Mr Gray would be deprived of the pleasure of receiving his friends this day— It was great relief to me being in a condition utterly unfit to meet any one in company— The night was again quite oppressive and I was twice in the course of it awaked with a racking cough— Mrs Charles finally prevailed on me to see Dr Bigelow— He came and I gave him a history of my case; which he said was the peripneumona notha, and prescribed for it, medicine, ale and a generous diet— I went with Mrs. Charles to visit Mrs Abbott Lawrence who was not at home, and Miss Leslie who was engaged.— We then parted, and I returned the visit of Mr George Tickner— He lives in a large and elegant house a life of ease and indolence, without seeming to take part in any thing that concerns this world, talking with indifference about men and things. I returned also the visits of Mr James Savage, and Mr Robert C. Winthrop, neither of whom was at home— The Revd Mr Lunt of Quincy called to see me and spoke of the very sudden decease in the course of the late winter of his aged Colleague Peter Whitney— I passed the day as with a mill-stone about my neck, working invita Minerva upon my address for the historical Society, unable even to get through with my daily task of two pages, and seeing as yet no point of departure for the discourse. hitherto I stumble one after another upon preliminary points of doubtful propriety to the occasion and more doubtful adaptation to the taste and prejudices of the day.— I find continual occasion to resort to books which I have not at hand— In discussing a confederacy of New England Colonies the subject leads to remarks upon the propriety of the name upon the special sympathies with the condition and characteristic properties of the mother Country old England and to a comparative notice of the elementary composition of the other colonies which now constitute jointly with us the North American Union. This has already brought me upon debatable ground, and upon the accursed domain of Slavery. What shall I do with it? I am upon the breakers, and know not how to draw off from them— The relations of the Colonies with the Indians also constitute another shoal which I have not yet reached but upon which I shall be in imminent danger of stranding.— I can scarcely express how in my weakened condition these thoughts weigh me down.

I was awaked only once in the Night, by a fit of coughing, and slept again till the dawn was far advanced— I had engaged to dine with Mr P. C. Brooks and my Son, at Dr Frothingham’s but my cough was this morning so troublesome that I thought it more prudent to decline dining in company, and was excused— Mr Quincy President of Harvard University, and his eldest daughter called to visit us, and the day was assiduously, but very unsatisfactorily occupied in search reading and writing upon my task— I am still on the preliminaries of my subject—still struggling for some heart of argument, not already fagged into common-place— My first spring of thought has been to discriminate between the Colonies of New-England, and the others which constitute our present confederate Government— In commenting upon this I meet the necessity of knowing, exactly the primitive titles of the several New-England Colonies— Mr Felt has lent me a volume published at Hartford in 1836. by R. R. Hinman Secretary of the State of Connecticut, consisting of Letters from the kings and Queens of England, to the Governors of the Colony of Connecticut, with their answers from 1635. to 1749— Much of this day was consumed in turning over the leaves of this book, to trace the origin of the colony of Connecticut, which is yet left to be accomplished— I found it also necessary to examine the first Volume of Hazard’s State Papers, but had not time to look into it— After labouring till close upon one O’Clock in this alternation of reading and writing, I went to Mr Felts N. 15. Warren Street, and borrowed the keys of the historical Society’s chambers. I found Mr Felt’s dinner smoking on the table, though he had not sitten down to it. I had scarcely reached the Society’s chambers when I was obliged to return home to dinner. Charles dined at Dr Frothingham’s— After dinner I wrote the journal of yesterday— Then read the remainder of Lord Brougham’s great Speech in the British house of peers, on his motion that the thanks of this house be given to Lord Ashburton for his treaty concluded last August with Mr Webster— It must be very imperfectly reported— The National Intelligencer of last Tuesday, announces that on the preceding day Mr Daniel Webster resigned the office of Secretary of State, and that the charge of the Department ad interim was taken by the attorney General Legare— And that on the same day Caleb Cushing was appointed Minister Plenipotentiary to China, in the place of Edward Everett who has declined the appointment. The reason of Mr Webster’s resignation is not explained— Dr and Mrs Frothingham spent part of the evening here.

There is no abatement of my Catarrhal cough, although there is some of the symptoms of other diseases with which it is complicated— I slept last night till the crepuscular dawn, which is now about half past 3 in the morning, and then awoke under a load which the racking cough of half an hour could only lighten but not cast off— It continued through the day without sign of mollification. I wrote with heavy heart and drooping spirits the journal yesterday—and then a Letter to my wife, which I could not even enliven with fancies to please her, as a man ought always to do in writing to his wife— Dr Bigelow paid me a second visit and I gave him the diagnostics of my present condition— His advice is still, ale and good living. I had a long visit from Mr Joshua Leavitt— Long conversation with him. He is to embark next Tuesday in the Steamer Britannia, to attend the second triennial world’s convention to promote the abolition of Slavery throughout the world to be held next month in London— I urged him to make close observations, so far as he should have opportunity, to ascertain the real policy of the British Government on this subject; entertaining as I do strong doubts of a compromise between their commercial and their moral policy, much too obsequious to the cause of Slavery for real fidelity to the cause of justice and of man— I desired him to say to Arnold Buffum, and to Joseph Sturge from me, that I intended to have written to each of them by him; but am prevented by my indisposition— And I intreated him as long as he should be there to keep his eye fixed upon Texas, Mexico, California, and especially on the Island of Cuba. He intimated to me that he intended as appropriate to his character he intended to bring before the Convention for consideration certain primary principles asserting the personal rights of men as always transcending the corporate right of Sovereignty— As I was going out I met at the door Commodore and Mrs Downes coming to visit my Son and daughter— Downes told me he did not know I was in the City. After shaving I went to the chambers of the historical Society where I found neither Church’s history of Philip’s War, nor Adair’s history of the Indians which I wanted, but I did find an original edition of John Smith’s history—and a collection of Old Colony Documents recently published by Dr Alexander Young. I had but a short hour at the Rooms, and on coming home, found Lieutt. Joseph H. Adams who dined with us— Under orders for Norfolk and is to go on Monday— Visits also from Mr and Mrs Edward Brooks— He, just returned from Brattleborough Vermont, where he went to see his sick brother Horatio. Mr P. C Brooks spent the Evening here

An uncommonly beautiful day— Summer like, but for a dash of East-wind—cool without being chilly. But not the least abatement of my Catarrh. Rather a heavy aggravation. Heard Dr Frothingham this morning. From 1. Timothy 2.4. “Who will have all men to be saved, and to come unto the knowledge of the truth”— The universality of the Christian faith was the subject but the sense in which the words should be used was to be understood To be saved in this passage, meant evidently to be converted to Christianity, and thereby come to the knowledge of the truth— But what was meant by all? very few— All included neither the inhabitants of Africa nor of Asia, the greater or the less, nor of a great portion of the rest of the earth nor even Palestine where Christ himself was born— But all in this text referred to the various classes and conditions of men, and its object was to shew how the blessings and promises of the gospel were adapted to every age, to either sex, to every class of human kind, and in that consisted the universality of christianity whereby the knowledge of the truth is obtained— The doctrine deduced from the discourse was the obligation upon all to devote themselves to the purposes which the gospel is destined to report. There was a notice read by Dr Frothingham of a meeting to be held by the Society next Thursday for considering a plan to alter and repair the Church— Immediately after the service, I called with Mrs Charles on Mrs Edward Brooks, whom we saw with her Son and daughter— The house belongs to Edward Everett, and is that in which he lived while he was Governor of the Commonwealth. When he went to Europe, it was occupied by Sidney Brooks who with his wife has a passion for elegant furniture, and when they also embarked last November for England, they left all their splendid furniture in the house which Edward Brooks took with more costly articles of his own, and now they all constitute the joint display of the lower rooms. They are monuments of the vanity of riches— They look like a cabinet makers shop in a Sculptor’s studion, and a painter’s gallery. Crimson satin sophas and curtains, easy and rocking chairs. Statues from a Colossal Apollo Belvidere to a naked woman on her knees, modern portraits and Italian paintings— Engravings of the Transfiguration and Guido’s Aurora, with Durand’s Declaration of Independence, and Trumbull’s Bunker hill were all clustered together but well disposed by the taste of Mrs Edward Brooks— After dinner, a very young man preached from Ecclesiastes. 1.–2 “All is vanity.” Soon after that services a succession of visitors— Closed the day— Harriet Welsh. Degrand at tea— Then Mr P. C. Brooks—and Edward Brooks’s Son.

Mr Savage, President of the Massachusetts historical Society called and I had a long conversation with him; chiefly upon a question fit only to make a learned body ridiculous by forming a subject for divided opinions and even of controversy. That is, on the day for the ceremony.— The day of the confederation was 19. May 1643— The day chosen for the celebration is the 29th. of May because at that time the difference between the Calenders was only ten days— But the difference is now two days more, and I told Mr Savage that as the 19th. of May of old Style of the present year is the 31st. of the new Style, I thought they should take the 31st. for the celebration— But he and judge Davis, have settled the point between themselves upon principle— He argued it with me astronomically and politically with such lucid illustration, that I lost the thread of his syllogism, and finally did not understand him at all. I went to visit Dr Frothingham, who was not at home, and I called on George Bancroft. I found Robert C. Winthrop with him, and of course we talked history— They were endeavouring to ascertain the relation between Sir John Temple, Winthrops grand-father and the Grenville family—of which I was surprized to see, Winthrop apparently not at all informed— Mr Bancroft had a number of manuscript Letters, which Edward Everett has collected for him, from Burke, Fox, Champion, Dr Franklin, Arthur Lee &c written in 1774—and among the rest a copy of Thomas Hutchinson’s account of his private interview, with King George the 3d. in July 1774. on Hutchinson’s first arrival from this country— He was introduced by Lord Dartmouth, and was upwards of two hours long with the king— Much of the dialogue, was upon the detection and exposure by Dr Franklin of Hutchinson’s Letters, upon which the king said that there was not a word in them at which any just exception could be taken— Bancroft told me that from this paper and all the other disclosures to which he has obtained of the real character of Hutchinson, he had come to the same conclusion that my father did—that he was a bad man.— This afternoon I had again a long professional visit from Dr Bigelow, and a discussion upon the proper regimen and treatment of the incurable disease with which I am afflicted, and for which I believe great abstemiousness and he thinks good living the appropriate, and only appropriate palliative remedy— He still persists in his opinion, and I shall conform myself to it, as long, and as well as I can— Dr George Parkman came to see me. He did not know that I was in the city till this morning— My intercourse with him is always friendly without alloy, and nothing more— At close of day I went with Charles’s wife in to their next door neighbour’s Mr Samuel D. Parker, and saw him—his daughter—niece and two sons, the youngest of whom is a student at the University. Visit afterwards from Mr Schuyler—of New-York.

My catarrh gives me not the slightest encouragement to expect relief from its visitation— The weather of yesterday and this day has been unusually fine, with a bright Sun and a balmy breeze— My daughter received last Night the intelligence of the death of her brother Horatio Brooks, at Brattleborough, Vermont— His life has been unfortunate, and yet his decease is afflictive— I packed up my trunk and sent it out at Noon by the Stage to Quincy.— Then wrote my journal for yesterday—and had written one page of my address, for the anniversary day—after a call on Cadmus, I took the last turn to the chamber’s of the historical Society where I found at last Adair’s History of the Indians— I could not take it out— But I did take out a copy of the 8th. volume of the 3d. series of the publications of the Society the volume recently published, and for which I left with my Son directions to pay. Louisa C. Smith was here great part of the morning. Shortly before noon, one of the black men concerned in publishing the Emancipator, brought me a note from Mr Joshua Leavitt, taking an affectionate leave of me, and enquiring of the state of my health, being on the point of departure in the Steamer Hibernia for Liverpool to attend the Meeting of the World’s Convention— I wrote on a small scrap of paper a few words, bidding him God speed and praying for him a happy return— A man by the name of John Howard from Springfield in this Commonwealth; came and made some enquiries about the Land in Guysborough Nova-Scotia, belonging to the Estate of the late Mr Ward N. Boylston, which land Mr Howard said he was told last year, when he was there, belonged to John Quincy Adams.— I told him I had no other interest in it than as an Executor and Trustee of Mr Boylston’s last Will; and referred him for further enquiries to Mr Nathaniel Curtis; but this incident reminded me that I have yet much to do for the settlement of that estate, and probably only the season now before me for doing it— Immediately after dinner, at 1/2 past 3. my son took me in his Gig out to my own residence at Quincy, where I found John Kirk and his wife ready to receive me— I have returned once at least every year for the last 15 years, to this calm retreat from public labours and boisterous passions with extasy of delight— Now dashed with a presentiment that it may probably be for the last time, and that the most imperious of my duties now is to set my household in order, and prepare for my last change. Charles returned to Boston— I walked round my Garden, Nursery and Seminary where I found a few of my young seedling trees which will still deserve my attention— The Rev’d Mr Lunt called and spent an hour of the Evening with me— I easily found occupation till 10. O’Clock and then with a severe fit of coughing retired to bed

No Relaxation of my disease— The repose of the Night broken as it has been every night since the return of my complaint.— But I rose this morning at 4. and was on my way to see the Sun rise from the S.E. corner of Charles’s house; when I found half his disk above the horizon— His first ray appeared 4:37.— I wrote upon my address for the anniversary—without any satisfaction, and under a deep impression of dulness beyond all redemption— The day was fair and the weather on the whole warm—though I had a small fire made. I visited my seedling trees— For these fifteen years I have seen, every year sowing in confusion which I have often and vainly endeavoured to methodize, the seeds of many fruit and forest trees— I have been here only a part of every year, and I have never paid due scientific regard to them— I have neglected all the instructions of Du Hamel, Forsyth, Loudon, and the other writers upon planting and dendrology— The result is that after numberless disappointments and the thorough failure of about 9/10ths. of my experiments I have perhaps one hundred trees growing from seeds sown by my own hands, and which if left unmolested where they now stand may survive me a full century and bear fruit for those who shall come after me— Of these, the only ones in which I now take much interest, are young apple trees, some just beginning to bear and others fit stocks for engrafting good fruit upon them.— About half a dozen pear stocks—one red oak 12 feet high and one foot in circumference, a dozen or more other Oaks, black, white and chesnut all neglected— Sundry elms and ash of which I might have a forest. Sundry cherries, most of them in bloom, but not having yet born fruit— Three maples the seeds of which I brought from Philadelphia in May 1836. and sowed on the first of June of that year. It is a comfort to me to leave these growing upon my grounds, and the sight of my trees bursting into bloom gives me the solitary pleasure that I enjoy in returning to this peaceful abode. I dined alone; and this afternoon my Son came out from Boston, with all his family to keep house with me, till he can get his own house upon the hill prepared for their reception— I got through my daily task of yesterday’s journal, and two pages of my address for the centennial— But this last sickens me to the heart and must prove a grievous failure— I am now wading through a comparative statement of the democratic ingredients of the four New-England Colonies which united in the confederacy of 1643. and find it hard to labour through.

I took last Night before going to bed by way of experiment a tumbler of wine whey, and it did not succeed— It aggravated my cough, and heated me without producing a perspiration— I rose in time to go over and see the sun rise from the corner of Charles’s house at 4.36. The restlessness of the Night somewhat dispirited me for punctuality to my labours so that I did not complete the two pages of my address for the day, nor finish my diary for yesterday, but by writing this evening till my bed time. But I spent between two and three of the best hours of the day, in going with John Kirk round my Garden and Nursery—trimming some of my trees, plucking up others, and preparing for clearing off the useless trees now stunting the growth of the precious ones—those for which I anticipate the longest lives are the shagbark walnuts of which I have about 20 from 12 to 2 years old, and the sight of which is a reward for all the labour I have wasted in raising tree, from the seed— In making up my summary of the 4 New-England Colonies which formed the confederacy of 1643. I have to consult numerous writers as well those nearly cotemporaneous as of later ages— Hutchinson is my standing leader, and often after finding, a very brief notice of my special object of enquiry, in him, with a reference to others for further enquiry, I stroll off to Hazard’s State papers, to Hinman’s Connecticut Antiquities, to Farmer’s Registers to Chalmers of Holmes Annals, to sundry volumes of the Collections of the Historical Society—and to others which I have not yet been able to gather. I return to the short notice in Hutchinson, and perceive not that I have much enlarged my stock of knowledge— Dr Holmes’s Annals are copious of facts—and they are what I want to know with most precision— I seek particularly the why and the when the Colonies of Connecticut and of New-Haven were organized and established— There is much modification of the history caused by the various phases of the revolution and restoration in of the Stuart family in England— I took up this day the Volume of Bancroft’s history recently published, and find a new colouring given to every incident, and a new gloss to every character— There is in every line of Bancroft a struggle to magnify the importance of events and of persons giving an air of pomposity to his whole Story— This afternoon I took a ride in the Carriage with Mrs Charles and her baby Arthur, to Braintree, where she finally found Miss Sampson, and engaged her to come, and work for her, the second week in June— Evening visit from Mr Beale— Short for I was drowsy.

Having no time to spare for the composition of my address for the Massachusetts historical Society, and deeming it necessary for the filling of the time allotted to the discourse, that it should consist of 32 pages, occupying two pages or thereabouts I begin the day with that labour, and prescribing to myself to write two pages each day till I get through— I began therefore this morning as soon after rising dressing and making my fire was practicable, and with the interval of half an hour for breakfast kept incessant alternate reading and writing, till the village bell rung for noon before my task for the day was completed— In the course of my treatment of the subject I was this day brought to the consideration of the character of Roger Williams and the establishment of the Colony of Rhode-Island— It has in recent times become a sort of literary fashion to extol the character of Roger Williams, by disparaging those of the Massachusetts with whom he contended. I have suspected that there is in this much injustice; and the more minutely I examine his controversy with them, the more firmly this opinion fixes itself in my mind— Roger Williams was a Welshman— He came sharpened for controversy, a polemical porcupine from Oxford, an extreme puritan quilled with all the quarrelsome metaphysical divinity of the age— He arrived eight months after Winthrop and his company and began by preaching at Salem that the Charter was of no avail, because the king had no power to grant the lands because they belonged to the Indians, and that the Church was no true Church because she had not proclaimed her repentance for having held Communion with the Church of England before the Emigration— These doctrines struck at the vitals of the Massachusetts Colony, civil and ecclesiastical— If there is any thing surprizing in their treatment of him, it was their lenity towards him— His principle of liberty of conscience admirable in itself, was utterly at variance with itself in his excommunication of the colonial church for not excommunicating the episcopal church of England— Altogether he was a mere boute-feu and they were amply justified in getting rid of him. I see that Bancroft tells his Story with extreme partiality to puff him up—not only to a Saint and Hero; but to a transcendent Genius— A Newton, Kepler, or Copernicus. His principle of Toleration was the inspiration of a strong mind, and his success in settling a small colony where it was carried into practise gives lustre to his name— The recent revolution in Rhode-Island, is the Euthanasia of his system— My son, took his daughter Louisa to Boston with him to Boston and returned to dine. And after dinner I took a ride in the Carriage with his wife and youngest son Arthur.

My nightly cough begins to subside and I am encouraged with a hope of temporary relief from the peripneumona notha which I suppose is to finish me upon earth—for the respite I desire to bless the name of God, and with it I must pray for a good deliverance from my tedious task of the 29th.— I am still entangled with the character and history of Roger Williams and his democracy of the Providence Plantations.— I fear to do him injustice in the anxious desire to do justice to his adversaries— I cannot but think him the aggressor against the Massachusetts Colony from the day of his arrival— I cannot acquit him of the ambition of supplanting John Cotton as the high priest of the Colony— He shuffled and equivocated in apologizing to the general Court for his first Treatise against the Charter and in offering it to them to be burnt— His excommunications were all intolerant. his refusal to take the oath of allegiance was factious—his preaching against it seditious— He appears to have prevaricated on the subject of his conversion to the anabaptist denomination.— And his last controversial writings against the Quakers might as well have been omitted— Yet his inflexible and finally triumphant principles of universal toleration makes him a name and a praise for all future time— I see sharp points shooting out from every side of the subject— I received this day 1. A Letter from R. F. Barnard President of the Berkshire County Agricultural Society, dated Sheffield May 18. inviting me to prepare and deliver an address before them at their annual Fair to be held on the first Wednesday and Thursday of next October. 2. A Letter from Charles Sedgwick, Daniel N. Dewey, George N. Briggs, and Franklin Sturgis dated 17. May, referring to the above Letter of Mr Barnard and adding their very earnest solicitations to me, to visit that part of the Country. 3. A Letter from Revd. Charles Lowell D.D. Secretary of the Massachusetts Historical Society, dated Boston 18. May, requesting me to write an hymn or ode for the celebration of the 29th. 4. A further printed circular Letter from Ellis Gray Loring dated 13. May, as Treasurer of the United States Hotel company, apprizing me of some new arrangements to be made by the Stock holders— All these Letters require answers— They should be immediate answers; but I have no time to write them— I wrote and despatched a short Letter to my wife— Mr and Mrs Lunt were here on a visit this afternoon— I took a ride with my daughter and her baby Arthur this Evening— We left Mrs Lunt at the door of her house, and came out where the Quarry railway crosses the road in Milton—

My cough has very much subsided, and I went to bed last Night without a fit of coughing, and awoke this morning with a very light one— Mr Lunt preached this morning from Luke 12.15—[“]for a man’s life consisteth not in the abundance of the things which he possesseth”—and Romans 8.6.—“to be spiritually minded is life and peace.”— Mr Lunt considered the second of these texts as an exposition of the first— The life of man he said was different from that of all merely material beings— The life of beasts and birds and fishes and all the animated creation consisted of the circulation of material elements—and in this sense there was a life in plants—perishable by the lapse of time but life in man was the conscious existence of the immortal soul, and therefore could not consist in the abundance of a man’s earthly possessions.— Mr Lunt gave notice that the afternoon service would be performed by a blind person named Bowen—who had been earnestly recommended to him by several of his professional brethren at the South, as every way, worthy of encouragement and kindness. He said that Mr Bowen, had been admitted to the pulpits of many churches in this neighbourhood, and had preached as he was informed to general acceptance.— He had thought it his duty to give him the same opportunity, and as Mr Bowen had no other means of providing for his subsistence, after his discourse a collection would be taken up for his benefit— Mr E. Price Greenleaf walked home with me— After dinner, Mr Bowen, the blind man preached from John 9.2. “And his disciples asked him, saying, Master, who did sin, this man, or his parents, that he was born blind? 3. Jesus answered, neither hath this man sinned, nor his parents: but that the works of God should be made manifest in him.”— Is there not in this answer an explicit declaration that the phyical infirmities and diseases of men are not to be considered as visitations of heaven upon them in punishment for transgression— Yet it is scarcely to be denied that there are punishments inflicted by heaven for sins upon earth— Mr Bowen’s discourse was intellectual as much as might be expected from one habitually living with knowledge at one entrance quite shut out.— Mr Bowen gave some statistics of blindness in different countries, and presented their plea for compassion without overcharge or exaggeration.— In thanking the auditory for their patience he repeated the notice given this morning by Mr Lunt, that he had no other means of obtaining his subsistence, but his preaching, and a liberal contribution was taken up for his benefit—

I find myself with the most unremitting labour unable to accomplish the daily task of writing two pages of my address, and equally so of fixing any point of view, in which the New England Colonial confederacy can be made interesting.— My acquaintance with the details of the original settlement of New England is very slender, and being now under the obligation to look them up, the streams of information are so copious, that they absorb all my time— The confederacy of 1643 was a defensive league against the Indians—my first duty was to trace the separate origin of the five New-England Colonies, including that of Rhode-Island and Providence plantations, which was not admitted into the league— Then I was cast upon the controversy concerning the life and character of Roger Williams. Next I came to the investigation of the Colonial Wars with the Indians— This plunges me into the historical collections of the Massachusetts, and of the Rhode Island historical Societies—of the Massachusetts Collections there are 28 volumes already published and of the Rhode Island collections 4: The Massachusetts collections are rich in original publications respecting the New England Indians, and the Wars of the European Colonists with them. In the first volume there is a work by Daniel Gookin, entitled Historical collections of the Indians of New-England of which I made this day the discovery, and which occupied hours of my time— The work is dedicated in December 1674. to Charles the 2d with an Epistle to Robert Boyle and the Society in London for propagating the gospel among the Indians, and another epistle to the reader— In the second Chapter of this work there is an enumeration of five tribes embracing all the tribes inhabiting New England when the English colonies were first settled, and continuing to exist half a century afterwards when Gookin wrote— This Daniel Gookin was father to Elizabeth Gookin, second wife of the second Edmund Quincy, ancestor of President Josiah Quincy. His first wife was Joanna Hoare, mother of Daniel Quincy and thereby my ancestor— I am yet to explore the narratives of the Indian Wars as originating causes of the New-England confederacy, and in the mean time, my address drags its slow length along. I took a ride this afternoon round through Braintree with my daughter and her baby Arthur.— Elizabeth C. Adams took tea here. They came from Medford on Saturday. We have the melancholy tidings of the death of Mr Whittemore the husband of Louisa De Wint, leaving two infant children.

Morning showery. Cleared off after Breakfast. Charles went to Boston with his daughter Louisa, and returned to dine— Mr Robinson the Minister of the episcopal church in this town called on me this morning and requested me to attend the Fair, at the vestry under the Church this afternoon, and to address the company who might be there. After dinner I rode with Mrs Charles and Arthur to Mrs T. B. Adams’s; left them there— Took up Elizabeth C. Adams and went to the Church vestry Fair— There were about twenty women there with tables before them covered with small articles for sale, and five or six men, and sundry children— The Fair is a small device for taxing the pockets of visitors for contributions— An expedient of beggary humble enough but growing stale— I purchased two or three petty articles; Mr Robinson who had formally announced me when I entered asked me again to let the ladies hear my voice— My voice was in no condition to speak, and I declined— I had in truth nothing to say; and knew not what to say— I returned with Elizabeth to Mrs T. B. Adams’s Took up Mrs Charles and the baby, and rode down to the Mount Wollaston beach where I am always reminded of the barge into which I enteredFebruary 1778 to embark in the Boston Frigate for France, and of my landing on the 2d. of August 1779 from the pinnace of the French frigate La Sensible on the same beach—65 years have passed away since the first of those events— Nearly 64 since the second— What changes of the globe and of man in that interval— The beach seems to be the same— We took Elizabeth home, and then came home. Evening call from Benjamin Owen Tyler—coming now from Duxbury where he has been varnishing for Gershom B. Weston— I was benumbed—and torpid, and fell asleep while Mr Tyler was talking, and slept till after he went away— I had been labouring all day, at the New-England confederacy of 1643. and made very little progress. See Collections of the Massachusetts Historical Society 3. 203 Abstract of Roger Williams’s Key in to the Language of the Indians of New-England. 5. Genl. B. Lincoln’s Observations on the Indians— Report of Jeremy Belknap and Jedidiah Morse about Indians and Missionaries— Letter from Stephen Badger about Natick Indians—p 6–45— Roger Williams, Vocabulary of the Narraganset Language p. 80— Brief account of Settlements in and about Narraganset Bay. p. 216–252. 6. Specimen of Indian languages. p. 16. Letter of Instructions from Leonard Hoar to Josiah Flint 27. March 1661. p. 100— Letters relating to the Natick Indians and Philip 1671. p. 196–211.— Dedications to Eliot’s Indian Bible 7. 222. Ecclesiastical History of Massachusetts and the old Colony of Plymouth— p. 262–280— I propose to continue this list, through the subsequent volumes of the Historical Collections—

Mr Benjamin Owen Tyler was again here this morning with his century of inventions for raising the wind— His principal project now is an engraved print for a temperance pledge certificate, ornamented with the portraits of sundry reformed drunkards, or according to the latest vocabulary, inebriates— He also convinced me by dint of persuasion, to let him varnish some of my old pictures. A person by the name of Alexander Wolcott Stow, formerly of Connecticut, now of Milwaukie, in the territory of Wiskonsin, came to see me and to have some conversation with me; as he said merely for the pleasure of it— A friend of Liberty Deacon Spear called also, and proposed to me at some future day to visit my territories, to which I agreed without naming a day. There was a fire in the Town this day, between Noon and One O’Clock, which consumed several dwelling houses, at some distance from each other— First caught from a foul chimney, and then carried by the wind in burning cinders from house to house.— Clift Rogers and Cotton Pratt, a Carpenter are two of the sufferers who lost their houses— After dinner I rode to Milton with my daughter and her boy Arthur—stop’d on our return at Mrs T. B. Adams’s to enquire how they were— Barely recovering from their fright— The fire was close in their neighbourhood, and their house was in imminent danger of being kindled— My progress to the completion of my Address to the Massachusetts Historical Society was suspended by my examination of the volumes of the Collections of the Society, for publications relating to the subject. The notice of which I now continue— First Series Vol. 8. p 5–35. Memoir of the Life of Rev’d John Eliot, called the Apostle of the Gentiles, who translated the Bible into an Indian Language, and was part author of the New-England Metrical version of the Psalms— p 203–239. Mourts Relation or Journal of a Plantation settled at Plymouth in New-England reprinted from Purchas’s Pilgrims Book 10. Ch. 4— London 1625. An abridgment— p. 239–276. E. Winslow—Good news from New-England—&c— Abridged in Purchas. Book 10. Ch. 5— Vol. 9. p. 1–49. Ecclesiastical History of Massachusetts. p. 77–102. Memoir of the Moheagan Indians 75–102— History of the Penobscott Indians, by James Sullivan— p 207–232— Vol. 10. Ecclesiastical history of Massachusetts continued p 1–37.— Memoirs of the Pequots and sundry other tribes of Indians p 101–154.— Grant of 50 pounds in money 11. October 1682 to William Hubbard for writing his History of New-England—

Mr White came with a subscription paper for the sufferers by the fire yesterday besides Pratt. The fire broke out in the Faxon house, property of the late Benjamin Faxon nearly opposite the orthodox Church, occupied by several Irish families— Crossed the street to the stable of Clift Rogers Currier. Sparks blown by the gale, kindled Henry Gardiner Pratt’s carpenter’s shop, and thence to his dwelling house—both burnt, and also the next adjoining dwelling house of Peter Brackett— Three houses, one stable, two shops—all consumed within the space of one hour— Loss about 3000 dollars. Seven families burnt out— Blessed be God—no lives lost— Wooden buildings stubble. Mr Tyler was here nearly all day, varnishing everything upon which he could lay his hand— I went to Boston with my Son, and we both attended a monthly Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society— There were about 20 members in attendance; and the arrangements were made for the delivery of my discourse next Monday— It is to be a religious ceremony with prayers and singing. At Dr Frothingham’s Church— There was a debate whether it should be in the morning or after dinner— Finally voted, that the Society shall meet at their chambers at half past 10. A.M.— Go from thence in procession to the church so as to commence the performances at 11.—so I hope it will be all over by half past one.— We returned home to Quincy to dine and I was occupied all the afternoon upon the diary and the Collections of the Massachusetts historical Society— I had written and despatched this morning a Letter to my wife— And received one from Mr Frye, with enclosures which must not be neglected— My cough has almost subsided, but leaves me, in a condition of sluggishness and torpidity such as I never before experienced— I cannot rouse my self to exertion, and I returned to my paper and dropped away from it in helpless impotence ten times in the course of this afternoon— Collections of Massachusetts Historical Society—Second Series Vol. 1. Ecclesiastical History of Massachusetts and Memoir of Dr John Eliot p. 194–211–248. Vol. 2. p. 1–45. John F. Schermerhorn— Report on Western Indians— E Johnson’s Wonder working Providence p. 49. 96. Vol 3. p. 128–161. Continuation of Johnson’s Wonder-working Providence. Letters respecting Hubbard’s History p. 286–290. Vol. 4. p. 1–51. Continuation of Johnson’s Wonder working Providence— p. 107–120. New Englands Jonas Cast up at London. E. Hazard’s Remarks on Schermerhorn’s Report p. 65— Volumes 5 and 6. General History of New-England, from its discovery to 1680. by Revd. William Hubbard— Vol 7. p. 1.–58—continuation of Johnson’s Wonder working Providence— p. 75–114. Rhode-Island State Papers.

Mr Tyler continues his varnishing atchievements and this day dined with us— An Irish woman of one of the families burnt out of the Faxon house came to plead her own cause with all the eloquence of distress, but she could not pronounce her own name so that I could remember it.— After dinner I rode with Charles and his wife to Roxbury to the garden of an Englishman named Walker at Roxbury, where he has sundry beds of tulips after the fashion of those at Haerlem in Holland— In one bed under a glass-frame there were 1200 bulbs with the stalk and cups, in every variety of colouring and of cost— We met there Mr Edward Brooks with his mother in Law, Mrs Boott, his wife and daughter— There was a printed advertisement of a sale at auction of all these plants one day next week— In one part of the bed Mr Brooks was noticing two of the tulips near together, as being remarkably handsome, when Mr Walker observed that the difference in value between them was of fifty cents and fifty dollars— I thought the fifty cent one the handsomest of the two— The wild and extravagant and most capricious taste for tulips is not yet extinct— Returning home just after crossing Neponsett Bridge, my fingers were so pinched with cold that I alighted from the carriage and walked two miles home; Charles’s son John Quincy came down from the Coachman’s box, and walked with me— The day for the delivery of my address is now so near at hand that I am excessively pressed for time to conclude. I have come at last to an abstract of the Articles of the New England confederacy with the view of closing by a parallel between them and the present North American confederation of the United States—but the attempt has brought me to a conviction of failing faculties so exquisitely painful, that I am tempted to wish that a return of my habitual disease may totally disqualify me for the performance on Monday and save me from the mortification of self exposure. Collections of Massachusetts Historical Society Second Series Vol. 8. Wonder working Providence concluded p. 1–39. Danforth papers p 46–112. Letter from Matthew Craddock to Captain John Endicott. p. 116— John Mason’s brief history of the Pequot War p 120–153— Letter of Roger Williams 1682. p 196. Pincheon Papers 1629. p 228–249. Biographical Memoir of father Rasles p 250.

The Sun rose clear, but I was yet in bed. And the sky soon clouded up for a Northeaster with showers of rain through the day— I came in my address to the parallel between the New-England confederacy of 1643. and the North-American confederacy of 1774.— I had some hopes on approaching this topic to bring up some interest with it—but it sinks under me— Not one of the motives which stimulated the puritans of 1643 to their confederacy of 1643 had the slightest influence in actuating the confederacy of 1774. The parties to the New-England Union were homogeneous— Those of the North-American Union were not only of heterogeneous but of hostile elements; and in the latter there was the ingredient of Slavery which poisoned the whole composition— I have touched upon it in this address; but on revisal propose to strike out all that I have written relating to it— This afternoon I rode with my daughter and her son Charles to Weymouth to enquire of the state of Mrs Mercy Tufts who has been very dangerously ill with the Erisypelas— We saw her two daughters Mercy and Susan, who told us she was somewhat better, though still confined to her bed— We rode home with a sprinkling rain and the evening was wintry cold— This family of Tufts are all that now remain of my childhood’s remembrance of Weymouth— Some of the earliest of my recollections are there, and the localities which remain unchanged bring them back, with a pungency for which I scarcely know how to account— I have no such reminiscences in Boston, because every thing there is changed; but spots of the old road through Braintree and Weymouth are precisely as they were seventy years ago—and a return to them seems to sweep away the interval of time, and to make me again a child— But there is not one individual of my grandfather Smith’s blood now living in Weymouth— Collections of the Massachusetts historical Society— Second Series Vol. 9.
