Heard this morning Mr Lunt from Hebrews. 1.1. [“]God, who at sundry times, and in divers manners spake in time past unto the fathers by the prophets.”— A Dissertation upon the Hebrew prophets. This subject has perhaps not been fully explored— Mr Lunt noticed the division made by the Jews of their sacred books into the historical, the poetical and the prophetical— The latter including only the books of Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel Daniel and the twelve minor prophets— But the term prophet is of much more extensive signification in the old testament than to include the authors of the sixteen prophetical books.— The Patriarchs Abraham Isaac and Jacob were prophets— The kings Saul and David and Solomon were prophets. During the time of the judges the prophets were called Seers; and in the case of Balaam, there is a description of the manner of their visions (Numbers 24.16) The prophet fell into a trance, but had his eyes open—and then he saw visions, and heard voices—and what he heard he was obliged to repeat— In the days of the kings there were schools of the prophets whence it would seem it was considered as an art or Science to be taught by human instruction. But the word of the Lord came indiscriminately to persons of all conditions, and the prophet Amos was among the herdmen of Tekoa— One of the greatest prophets was Elijah, of whom there are now no writings left and it is remarkable that the 16. prophets whose writings are included in the Bible, all lived very shortly before or during the Babylonian captivity. By the Law of Moses, (Deuteronomy 13 and 18) a false prophet if he spoke in the name of the Lord—and a true prophet if he spoke in the name of any other God were to be put to death— The test of a true prophet who spoke in the name of the Lord was that his predictions should come to pass— And there was a promise that the Lord would raise up a prophet, like unto Moses; but it was not said when and the modern Christian commentators have concluded that this promise was fulfilled by the advent of Jesus Christ— But he, and by his declaration even John the Baptist was more than a prophet. Mr Lunt gave notice that the communion would be administered next Sunday. Mr Edward Brooks junr came out from Boston and dined with us. After dinner Mr Hall of Dorchester preached from Acts 16.30. “what must I do to be saved?” There was something startling in the text, but Mr Hall thought it a question, which every Christian ought to put to himself, every day and every hour of his life.— But he did not very distinctly define what he understood by being saved— He is no believer of eternal damnation— I this day painfully brought to a conclusion my address, to be delivered to-morrow before the Massachusetts Historical Society.

At 9 this morning I went with Charles into Boston and we stop’d at Dr Frothingham’s. There by a mistake rather ludicrous I was shown into his study where were assembled a number of persons, who I supposed were the Massachusetts historical Society though I could not conceive how they came there— Mr Peter C. Brooks was presiding, and they settled their Treasurer’s Accounts, made all their annual elections, and chose the Revd. Ezra Stiles Gannett as a member of their corporation in the place of the late Doctor William E. Channing before I discovered that it was a meeting of the Massachusetts Congregational charitable Society— When they had finished their business President Quincy who was there took me in his barouche to the chambers of the historical Society, where a meeting well attended was held— The President James Savage moved that the meeting should adjourn to his house at 8 O’Clock this evening and gave a general invitation to all the members present to attend there— A Procession was then formed in which I walked with President Savage to the first Church in Chauncey Place where I delivered the address to the Massachusetts Historical Society, in celebration of the second centennial anniversary of the New-England colonial confederacy of 1643.— The performances began precisely at 11. O’Clock, with an appropriate prayer by Dr Frothingham the Minister of the Church— Then the Psalm 107. of the New England version of 1640. was sung— I then delivered my address, beginning at 20 minutes past 11. and closing at 5 minutes past 1.— One hour and three quarters; omitting about one eighth of what I had written— It was very well received; and there was no manifestation of what I most dreaded, a sense of weariness on the part of the auditory— The attention was general and unremitting to the last— The house was well filled but not crowded— Excepting the members of the Society about as many women as men— After the Address, Psalm 44 of the New England version was sung, and the benediction was pronounced by Dr Frothingham.— Mr William Beach Laurence, Mr John Jay, and several other gentlemen were introduced to me as delegates from the historical Societies of New-York, Connecticut and Maine. I went with Charles and dined at Dr Frothingham’s— Charles’s wife dined at her brother Edward Brooks’s. At 4 in the afternoon we left Dr. Frothingham’s, and returned immediately to Quincy. Mr Buckingham’s son; part Editor of the Courier asked the loan of my manuscript to report an abstract from it—but I had promised to reserve it for the Society— My voice held out better than I expected, but I excused myself from attendance at the President’s evening party.

Mr Thomas Greenleaf called on me this morning, with a copy of a lease executed in 1839 of a lot of land belong to the Adams temple and school corporation for 20 years on a ground lent of 6. dollars a year— There was a condition inserted in the draught of the deed that at the termination of the lease, if the parties could not agree upon its renewal the corporation should take the buildings erected by the lessee, at an equitable apprizement— The supervisors of the fund disapproved of this condition; and directed that another should be done. But from the loose and careless manner in which the business of this corporation, and indeed of most others is transacted the conclusion of the deed has been neglected and protracted to this day—once signed and sealed by the selectmen, and acknowledged before a justice of the peace; but by unaccountable negligence without signature of witnesses; so that it must be done all over again— An admonition which ought not to be overlooked— Charles went into Boston to attend a Collation furnished by the Unitarian laymen of Boston to the Clergy of their denomination. This is a yearly festival; at which there were this day 815 persons of both sexes present— Charles presided as a delegate from Dr Frothingham’s Society at one of 8 tables.— The entertainment consisted of cold meats, tea and coffee— No wine or Spirits, but addresses and songs— I rode this afternoon with Mrs Charles, her Sons Charles, Henry and Arthur with his Nurse Becca—we stop’d at Mr John Greenleaf’s; and saw him and Mrs Greenleaf and their two daughters Mrs Lucy Dawes and Mrs Mary Dawes—after which we rode round the Braintree square, and when we reached home found Charles returned from Boston— I visited my garden, Nursery and seminary, and examined my seedling trees, many of which exhibit appearances, for which I cannot account— Almost all my peach-trees are winter killed; and among them several of two and three years old; and till now of the fairest promise— On the other hand the cherries all flourish more than I have ever known them to do before— The black walnuts often before blighted are uncommonly thrifty now: and the oaks and Shagbark walnuts differ so much that numbers of them have put forth a vigorous growth, while others after opening a beautiful foliage have already withered and are irretrievably blasted— The apples make as yet the fairest show.

Mr Lewis Tappan and Mr Andrews visited me this morning. Mr Tappan had with him the New-Orleans Bee of 15 and 16. May containing several long Articles, sounding the trumpet of alarm at the symptoms recently manifested in Texas of a strong party with a fixed design to abolish Slavery— The Bee has the name of Henry Clay on its first page nominated as its candidate for the presidency but its groans at the prospect of abolition in Texas are agonizing.— Mr Andrews is a native of Massachusetts, but at present an inhabitant of Texas— He is the person mentioned in the Letter from Joseph Eve, to the Secretary of State shewn to me by Mr Hunter on the 14th. of April— Eve related that this person had come from Austin to Galveston to make a speech in public urging the expediency and necessity of abolishing Slavery. But that an assemblage of people had gone to him at his lodgings, taken him by force and landed him at Virginia point on the opposite bank of the river. Mr Andrews says this was true; but that the men who committed this outrage upon him were a gang of not more than 20 persons; not at all authorised or supported by the People—and that he afterwards returned to Galveston, openly avowing his abolition opinions without meeting any ill treatment or opposition— He says he knows that the Texan President Houston is in favour of the abolition— He is now about to embark in the Steamer Caledonia to morrow for England, with a view to obtain the aid of the British Government to the cause— Mr Tappan asked me if I would furnish him with Letters of recommendation, which I declined having no correspondent in England with whom I could take the Liberty: but I bade him God speed and told him, that I believed the freedom of this country and of all mankind depended upon the direct, formal, open and avowed interference of Great-Britain to accomplish the abolition of Slavery in Texas. But that I distrusted the Sincerity of the present British Administration in the Anti-slavery cause. Mr Andrews offered to write to me, to inform me how his propositions may be received, which I accepted— Mr Tappan told me he had himself been urged to go to England and asked my advice what he should do— I declined advising; but said I wished he would go; were it only for the possibility that he might contribute to advance the cause— Edward and Mrs Brooks, with their daughter and Mrs Frothingham came out this afternoon and took tea with us.
